sect1.title: Downloading Zapatec DHTML Widget Files
sect1.para: The DHTML Widget files are bundled in a zip file. Click the download link in the appropriate widget section on Zapatec web site and follow the instructions to download the file.
Save the zpSomeWidget.zip file to your website root folder on the computer or server.

listitem.para: On your computer, browse to the folder where you saved the zpSomeWidget.zip file.
zpSomeWidget.zip contains a folder called zapatec that holds all the files you need to create your widget.

chapter.title: Setting Up Your Widget
chapter.para: In your web editor (Dreamweaver, UltraEdit, etc.), open the web page where you want the widget instance to be placed. Position a cursor before the ending </head> tag. Paste the following script paths before the ending </head> tag. For example,
chapter.programlisting: <!-- Javascript Zapatec utilities file --> <script type="text/javascript" src="utils/zapatec.js"></script> <!-- Javascript file to support your widget instance --> <script type="text/javascript" src="zpSomeWidget/src/SomeWidget.js"></script>
chapter.para: The zapatec.js file, which contains the general Zapatec utilities, is located in the utils folder.
The SomeWidget.js file contains sources of the specified widget and resides in the src subfolder in the zpSomeWidget folder.

To combine several widgets in a single web page, follow the instructions for inserting the header files given for the individual components. Include a single copy of the zapatec.js file and the core files for the components you are using. For example, if you are using the window and menu components, the header will be:
chapter.programlisting: <!-- Javascript Zapatec utilities file --> <script type="text/javascript" src="../utils/zapatec.js"></script> <!-- Javascript file to support window --> <script type="text/javascript" src="../zpwin/src/window.js"></script> <!-- Javascript file to support menu --> <script type="text/javascript" src="../zpmenu/src/zpmenu.js"></script>

chapter.para: This chapter provides information on how to create your own instance of the widget by inheriting the basic super class functionality and extending it to suite your needs. The sections in this chapter represent the logical consequence of actions to be performed for the proper construction and functioning of your widget class.

sect1.title: Predefined Configuration Options
sect1.para: The following section outlines the configuration options that are predefined in the base Widget class and will be inherited by your widget instance:

sect2.title: theme (string)
sect2.para: This option defines the theme name that will be used to display the widget. Corresponding CSS file will be picked and added into the HTML document automatically. The string value is case insensitive. The default value is "default". The string may also contain relative or absolute URL to the themes directory. E.g. "../themes/default.css" or "http://my.web.host/themes/default.css".
The special theme "auto" is used to detect a theme automatically depending on OS. It is replaced automatically with any of the following values:
Make sure all these themes exist before using "auto" theme for the widget.

sect2.title: themePath (string)
sect2.para: Use this option to set the relative or absolute URL to the themes directory. Trailing slash is required. The default value: a path to the child widget's file + "../themes/". You may also specify the path in the theme option instead of using themePath option.

sect2.title: asyncTheme (boolean)
sect2.para: By using this option you may load your theme asynchronously. Consequently, the script execution will not be suspended until theme is loaded. Your theme will be applied once it is loaded. This option defaults to FALSE.

sect2.title: templateFile (string)
sect2.para: URL of the template file, absolute or relative to the widget's js file. Default: "../templates/default.html". File extension must be "html".

Alternatively, this option may contain only template name. Example: "default". In this case URL of the file will be formed automatically from the template name, and the value of the templatePath config option.

Template file is supposed to contain a set of templates used in the widget. Each template must be enclosed in <textarea> tag having ID, which is used as a template name in templates config option. Each <textarea> tag must have the style attribute with "display: hidden". See the following for example,
sect2.programlisting: textarea id="zpWidgetTemplateMain" style="display: none
sect2.para: Each template is an HTML source passed to a new Zapatec.Template.

sect2.title: templateFilePath (string)
sect2.para: URL of the templates directory, absolute or relative to the widget's js file. Default: "../templates/". Trailing slash is mandatory. Path specified in the templates config option overwrites this config option. Use only if you pass the template name instead of the URL in the templateFile config option.

sect2.title: templates (object)
sect2.para: This option associates template IDs from the template file with template names. Specific for each widget. See the following for example,
Where "main" is the template name and "zpWidgetTemplateMain" is the template ID in the templates file.

Templates are initialized, and then each template (Zapatec.Template) object can be accessed using its name. Example: this.templates.main is a reference to the Zapatec.Template object, which was initialized with HTML source taken from "zpWidgetTemplateMain" textarea.0

sect2.title: source (string or object)
sect2.para: This option defines the source of data to be retrieved by the widget. The data source depends on the sourceType option value.
The source option is used together with the sourceType option. For the details on correspondence between the source and sourceType values, see the following table:

row.entry: [object or string] HTMLElement or its id.
[object or string] JSON object or string
[object or string] XMLDocument object or XML string.

sect2.title: sourceType (string)
sect2.para: Use this option together with the source option to specify how source should be processed. Possible source types: "html", "html/text", "html/url", "json", "json/url", "xml", "xml/url".

sect2.title: sourceFetchMethod (string)
sect2.para: The sourceFetchMethod option enables you to set either GET or POST as a source fetch method. The default value is GET.

sect2.title: sourceFetchContentType (string)
sect2.para: Use this option to define the content type when the sourceFetchMethod is set to POST.

sect2.title: sourceFetchContent (string or object)
sect2.para: If the sourceFetchMethod is POST, this option specifies a postable string or the DOM object data.

sect2.title: callbackSource (string)
sect2.para: You may use this option instead of source, sourceType and sourceFetchMethod configuration options to get source depending on the passed arguments. The option receives object with the passed arguments and should return the following object:
sect2.programlisting: { source: [object or string] see the above table for possible sources, sourceType: [string] see the above table for possible source types method: [string, optional] method ('GET' or 'POST'), contentType: [string, optional] content type when using POST, content: [string or object, optional] postable string or DOM object data when using POST }

sect2.title: asyncSource (boolean)
sect2.para: For possibility of loading source asynchronously, use the asyncSource boolean. As a result, the script execution will not be suspended until the source is loaded. The source will be processed without delay once it is loaded. By default, this option is set to TRUE.

sect2.title: reliableSource (boolean)
sect2.para: If the sourceType option is defined as a "json" or "json/url", using reliableSource boolean will help you skip JSON format verification. This will save time when loading large data sets. By default the boolean value is set to TRUE.

sect2.title: callbackConvertSource (function)
sect2.para: This option may be used to convert input data passed with the source configuration option from the custom format into the widget internal format. It should return the converted source.

sect2.title: eventListeners (object)
sect2.para: The eventListeners option is used to define an associative array with event listeners. For details on setting this option, see the code below:

sect2.para: By using this option you may set the unique id for the widget instance on your page.

sect2.title: this.constructor.path (string)

sect1.title: Localization
sect1.para: You can make your widget to display messages in any language. To do this, you need to set langID, langCountryCode and langEncoding properties.
The langID property value should be a 2-letter acronym taken from http://www.loc.gov/standards/iso639-2/php/code_list.php By default, langID is set to "en".
The langCountryCode property value should contain 2-letter country name acronym (see ISO 3166). Optional. You can omit it.
The langEncoding option sets the character encoding. By default it is undefined.
If you intend to use the language other than English, you also have to add this line of code to your page. See the following Form example for details:
This will attach a message file with resources for this language. Now it is possible to use langID: pt (Portuguese), langCountryCode: br (Brazil) and langEncoding: utf8.

sect2.title: Using Localization
sect2.para: Use the getMessage(key,[sub1,sub2...]) method to get your message localized. It gets the message for the given key, makes the substitutions and returns localized message.
The first parameter to be passed to this method is a key for which you want to get the message localized. All the other parameters are optional, they represent substitutions.

sect2.para: You can use tokens %1, %2, %3 in every string. The getMessage method can accept as many parameters as you wish. Each parameter that you have listed will be substituted by the given arguments and returned by getMessage(). If you have specified more arguments than the number of tokens in the appropriate line, then all the arguments will be shown "as is".

sect2.para: You can create or modify the resource file for you language. Use zpwidget/lang/default.js as a template. Use remarks and comments to make the correct translation.

note.para: Do not remove any keys from that file, even if you consider them irrelevant. Your widget may not function properly after that.

sect2.para: After you are through with translation, rename this file considering these 3 rules:

sect1.title: Communication API
sect1.para: Base Widget class provides APIs for widget communication:

sect2.title: Overview
sect2.para: Communication API is intended to provide a way to exchange data between different widgets. It gives ability to extract and transfer data from one widget to another, process the data and return processed data back to the sending widget.

Possible application: use one widget as editor for other widget, append one widget via another, communicate data between widgets, present data in different format, etc. Available ways of usage depend on the API implementation in the specific widget.
Communication API can be used to exchange data between widgets of the same type as well as between different types of widgets provided that those types have implemented this API.

sect2.title: Functional Specification
sect2.para: Communication API consists of several methods defined in the base Widget class. There are three groups of methods in the API:

listitem.para: Receive Methods — methods that must be implemented in the widget to enable the widget to receive data sent to it: receiveData.

Reply Methods — methods that must be implemented in the widget in addition to Receive Methods to be able to send the processed data back to the sending widget: replyData, replyDataCancel, replyDataReturn.
Accept Methods — methods that must be implemented in the sending widget to be able to receive data back from the editor: acceptData

sect2.para: To use your widget as a viewer, you must define input data format and extend receiveData method responsible for input data processing.

To use your widget as an editor, you must at least extend replyData method. It must prepare and return data in the same format as it was received in the receiveData method (format previously defined by you).

To be able to receive data back from editors, you must extend acceptData method in the widget. It is used as a callback function. It receives the editor widget instance and data. Use the JavaScript instanceOf operator to determine the type of editor widget and respective input data format. Parse returned data depending on widget from which this method is called.
Optionally you may use other methods.

sect2.title: Public Methods
sect2.para: You can load data passed from the other widget for viewing or editing using the receiveData method. To do this, pass the widget name and data in the format specific for this widget as parameters for this function. It fires the receiveData event. The listener receives argument object passed to this method.

The replyData method converts processed data to return it to the sender in the format the data was received by the receiveData function. It returns processed data in the format specific for the sender widget.

You may also want to cancel processing of the data received from the sender widget. In this case you should use the replyDataCancel method. As a rule, this method just hides the widget by calling the hide method if it is defined). The replyDataCancel event is fired before the widget is hidden.

To return processed data to the specified widget (not necessary to the sender widget), use the replyDataReturn function. Fires the replyDataReturn event before passing data to the specified widget. Listener receives argument object passed to this method.

Use the acceptData method to receive data back from the other widget previously passed to it by the receiveData method. It fires the acceptData event. The listener receives the argument object passed to this method.

sect2.title: Use Cases
sect2.para: Currently Communication API is implemented in the Grid. This allows to select certain rows from one grid and display them in another grid in a different format. It is also possible to use such widgets as Calendar and Editor for editing grid cells. See the Compare Rows and the Editors demos for details.
Communication between the From and the Grid functions as follows:

Instance of the Form is initialized before grid initialization and is hidden. For example, a new instance of the form is assigned to oForm variable, and a new instance of the grid is assigned to oGrid variable. oForm is passed to oGrid through special config option during initialization of the grid.

When the user clicks on a row, onclick event handler shows the form, calls oForm.receiveData method and passes the row into it in the format defined by the Form. oForm.receiveData method populates the form. Along with data it can pass oGrid instance to save reference to it in the form object for later use when Save button is clicked.

When the user clicks on Save button, its onclick event handler calls oForm.replyDataReturn({widget: oGrid}), which in its turn passes data back to the grid through oGrid.acceptData method (oGrid.acceptData is a callback). oForm.replyDataReturn calls oForm.replyDataCancel to hide the form.
If the user clicks another row while the form is opened, onclick event handler doesn't need to hide and show the form again. It just populates opened form by calling its oForm.receiveData method.
If the user clicks somewhere outside the grid, the form can be closed by calling oForm.replyDataCancel.

The eventListeners option is ignored by this method as it is only useful on initialization. To add an event listener after the widget was initialized, use the addEventListener method instead.

sect2.title: replyData
sect2.para: This method converts the processed data into the same format as it was received in Zapatec.Widget.receiveData(). The processed data will be returned in the format specific for each widget by replyDataReturn method.

sect2.title: replyDataCancel
sect2.para: Use this method to cancel processing of the data received from the other widget via Zapatec.Widget.receiveData(). This is usually realized by hiding widget instance (calling the hide method of the widget if it is defined).
The method removes the private dataSender property.
The replyDataCancel event is fired before the widget is hidden.

sect2.title: replyDataReturn
sect2.para: This method returns processed data to the specified widget (not necessarily to the widget from which they were received in Zapatec.Widget.receiveData()). It passes data to the Zapatec.Widget.acceptData() method of that widget, and then calls Zapatec.Widget.replyDataCancel() to hide this widget.
The following argument object format should be received as a parameter:
If the receiver widget was not specified, this method uses the widget passed to theZapatec.Widget.receiveData() method and saved in the private dataSender property.
The replyDataReturn event is fired before passing data to the specified widget. The event listener receives the argument object passed to this method.
